q: What are the symptoms of a broken hip?
a: Symptoms of a broken hip include pain in the hip or upper leg, swelling and bruising around the hip and leg, difficulty standing or putting weight on the affected hip and leg, and an odd angle or shorter length in the affected leg.

q: What immediate action should I take if I suspect a broken hip?
a: If you have severe hip pain after a fall or injury, are unable to walk or put weight on your leg, or experience tingling or loss of feeling in your hip or leg after an injury, you should call 999 or go to A&E.

q: When should I seek urgent advice for hip pain?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if you have severe hip pain that started suddenly without a fall or injury, if your hip is swollen and feels hot, if the skin around your hip has changed color, or if you have hip pain along with feeling generally unwell with a high temperature or feeling hot and shivery.

q: What is the treatment for a broken hip?
a: A broken hip needs to be treated in the hospital. Usually, painkillers are given and an X-ray is taken to determine the best treatment. Surgery is often required, which may involve fixing the bones back into place using screws, nails, rods, or plates, or replacing the damaged hip joint with either an artificial part (hemiarthroplasty) or an artificial joint (hip replacement).

q: What is the recovery time for a broken hip?
a: Recovering from a broken hip can take several weeks or months, and sometimes even longer. Most people spend around 1 to 4 weeks in the hospital and receive physiotherapy to help regain movement. Upon leaving the hospital, exercises will be recommended to continue at home. It's important to note that full recovery of strength and movement may not be possible, and assistive devices like walking sticks or frames may be needed.

q: How long do I need to stay in the hospital after a broken hip?
a: Most people with a broken hip spend around 1 to 4 weeks in the hospital.

q: What can I expect during the recovery period for a broken hip?
a: During the recovery period, you will start having regular physiotherapy sessions to aid in standing and movement. It's important to do the recommended exercises regularly to improve strength and movement. Some individuals may require assistance from carers or other health professionals when returning home.

q: Will I be able to fully recover my strength and movement after a broken hip?
a: While recovery varies for each individual, it's possible that you may never regain the same strength and movement as before the break. You may need to use walking aids such as a walking stick or frame. It's important to follow the recommended exercises and work closely with your physiotherapist for the best possible outcome.

q: What should I do to aid in recovery from a broken hip?
a: It's important to follow the exercises recommended by your physiotherapist regularly. This will help in the recovery process and improve your strength and movement.

q: Will surgery be required for a broken hip?
a: In most cases, surgery is required to treat a broken hip. The type of surgery will depend on factors such as your age and the type of break. It may involve fixing the bones back into place or replacing the damaged hip joint with an artificial part or joint.

q: What are the symptoms of a broken hip?
a: Symptoms of a broken hip include pain in the hip or upper leg, swelling and bruising around the hip and upper leg, inability to stand or put weight on the affected hip and leg, difficulty moving the hip and leg, and the affected leg being at an odd angle or shorter than the unaffected leg.

q: What immediate action should I take if I suspect a broken hip?
a: If you have severe hip pain after a fall or injury, are unable to walk or put weight on your leg, or experience tingling or loss of feeling in your hip or leg after an injury, you should call 999 or go to A&E.

q: What should I do if I have severe hip pain without a fall or injury?
a: If you have severe hip pain that started suddenly but you haven't had a fall or injured your hip, and you are experiencing swelling, changes in skin color, or feeling unwell with a high temperature or shivers, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or seek help from NHS 111.

q: What is the treatment for a broken hip?
a: A broken hip needs to be treated in the hospital. Usually, painkillers will be provided, and an X-ray will be taken to determine the best treatment option. Most people will require surgery to fix the broken bones or replace the damaged hip joint.

q: How long does it take to recover from a broken hip?
a: Recovery from a broken hip usually takes several weeks or months, though it can sometimes take longer. Patients typically spend around 1 to 4 weeks in the hospital and continue with physiotherapy and exercises at home.

q: Will I regain the same strength and movement after a broken hip?
a: It is possible that you may not regain the same strength and movement you had before the hip fracture. Some individuals may need to use assistive devices like a walking stick or frame, and some may require additional help from carers or healthcare professionals.

q: How important are the recommended exercises for recovery?
a: Doing the exercises recommended by your physiotherapist regularly is crucial for your recovery. These exercises will help improve your strength and movement.

q: What types of surgery may be performed for a broken hip?
a: Depending on factors like age and the type of break, surgery for a broken hip may involve fixing the broken bones with screws, nails, rods, or plates, replacing some of the damaged hip joint with an artificial part (hemiarthroplasty), or replacing the entire damaged hip joint with an artificial joint (hip replacement).

q: How soon after arriving at the hospital will surgery be performed?
a: Surgery for a broken hip is typically performed on the same day or the day after you arrive at the hospital.

q: Do I need assistance from carers when I go back home after a broken hip?
a: Some individuals may require assistance from carers or other healthcare professionals when they move back home after a broken hip, depending on their specific needs.
